texts.definition: People, possibly former, current, or future players, who observe the actions that players do in a game without being able to affect the game themselves.
markups: <style="Definition">People, possibly former, current, or future players, who observe the actions that players do in a game without being able to affect the game themselves.</style>

Not all people who can observe the development of a game played are players. Those who cannot directly affect the game as a player are <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>. While these do not experience gameplay directly, they can gain an experience from watching the game and can learn or prepare to play the game.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Players whose avatars are killed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike</link></style> have to wait until the next game begins before being able to play. Depending on the server, they may be able to watch as <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> while they are waiting or can only view a scoreboard.

Most tournaments, e.g. within <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soccer">Soccer</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style>, have <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> to the individual games that are played. This allows people participating in the tournament but not in the individual game to follow the gameplay as well as letting other interested people follow the whole tournament.

Games that take place in public environments, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ConQwest">ConQwest</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Insectopia">Insectopia</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Momentum">Momentum</link></style> , cannot help but be observed by non-players. If these <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> are aware that they are witnessing gameplay is another issue though. In the case of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Day%20of%20the%20Figurines">Day of the Figurines</link></style>, it is easier to say that people are aware since one part of the game is a public installation at a museum where people can view the positions of all players' characters in the game world.
<style="H4">Anti-Examples</style>

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> that depict <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> or car races, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Wii%20Sports">Wii Sports</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FIFA%20series">FIFA</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gran%20Turismo%20series">Gran Turismo series</link></style>, have diegetic <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> in their games. But since these are not actual people watching the events taking place,
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can either be people who will not be players at all in a game session at all or be used to give players information about the game while not playing or being able to act within it. In either case, they need to be provided with some form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Public%20Information">Public Information</link></style> in order to be considered <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> as they otherwise have no information about the game state.

Players currently in a game can temporarily become <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> by <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> (this is more or less impossible to hinder in games with <style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style> unless the players themselves do not wish it), and making players into <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can be used to instantiate <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> as a form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> can as <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> be given <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> for a short period of time before joining the game to let them be aware of the current situation within the game. Games which have <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style>, especially <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> but also <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style>, can use <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> to allow the eliminated players to continue to follow the gameplay.

There are many ways of supporting non-player <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>. First, many games inherently support <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> with some possibility to get an insight to a game in progress. This includes traditional <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Miniature%20Games">Miniature Games</link></style> but typically not <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>. Most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> also allow <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> simply by letting them view the display showing the game, but understanding the game situation may be difficult in fast-paced games or games heavily relying on interaction between different players. Games with <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style> often cannot help having <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> but in these cases, the people watching may not be aware that they are seeing gameplay actions. <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> doesn't in itself create <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> but provide designers with more control of the likelihood of possible <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> noticing the actions.

Games that specifically want to support <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>, can do so in several ways. <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="public-player-statistics">Public Player Statistics</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="replays">Replays</link></style> can be used let <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> (and possible future players) gain information about previous gameplay activities while <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style> can be used to push such information into other media than the one supporting or mediating the game.

While watching the actions of players may be the naturally most interesting activity of <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>, any type of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> be help provide interest to a game since they provide seeming intent to what happens in the games. Further, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> are like to be more interesting since here players are either intentionally competing or cooperating to achieve certain goals. <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> may by themselves or by encouragement by game facilitators modify their interest in the watch games by making <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>, with <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> on the outcome of the game as the most common example of this.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>
<style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> is an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

Having <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> that can observe gameplay can be both good and bad for gameplay that requires <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>; <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can encourage players to perform better but can also cause <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> related to this performance. The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> allows players to show their <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> and from this display gain <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>, especially when difficult or complex gameplay actions like <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style> are required. Allowing people to be <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>, as for example is common in <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>, make it possible for these people to gain <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> about the game and players may act as mentors through showing how to perform possible actions. This is possible even if games with no players, i.e. <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style>, since the <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can learn simply from observing what gameplay actions work in given situations.

When <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can communicate with the players either through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, this allow for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> between, making it possible to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> even in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>. This may however also lead the <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> to willing or not, and knowingly or not, provide <style="Link"><link="non-player-help">Non-Player Help</link></style>. When the <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> are aware of the gameplay in progress and try to influence the development of the gameplay by giving advice and commands, this can instead become a case of <style="Link"><link="backseat-gamers">Backseat Gamers</link></style>. An alternate to all this is to provide dedicated <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> to the <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> or support players in doing <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> that can give information to the <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> is also a <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Role</link></style> players can have in games. The possibility of being <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can help <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> to understand the current game state before joining a game. Likewise, being able to observe the states of <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style> can help players judge if they need to start playing actively or can let the <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style> continue with their automated behavior.

While it can be argued that no game is being played unless somebody is performing gameplay actions, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can question this argument. Specifically, <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style> or games with <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style> can be meaningful if <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> (which may be players in the sense that they may have set up in advance the actions being done) are allowed to observe the gameplay as it unfolds.

<style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> can be cast as <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> in games. While this is most easily conceivable in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Alternate%20Reality%20Games">Alternate Reality Games</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Pervasive%20Games">Pervasive Games</link></style>, it can be used in most games to make the <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> have more agency or unpredictability that if they are controlled by algorithms.

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Spectators</style> allows people that are not players in one game to be players in <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> based upon the game, e.g. <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> on the outcome.
